page.title: 17ATTITUDES 1
page.content: Most people who live in Pitlochry are there by choice; it is a popular retirement area. However, this is not always the case: within our area is a National Children's Home. John Ford, recently arrived from Dundee, has fresh impressions of Pitlochry and its good and bad points. Pitlochry, to him, appears quiet, peaceful, with an air of somnolence, which together with the scenery, the better housing and the lack of vandalism make it a pleasant place to stay. But there were problems: inadequate transport services, lack of sports facilities, especially a swimming pool, and poor, over- priced shops. For someone like John, Pitlochry has some of the qualities of a refuge, so much so that he does not look forward to returning to the big city.
